title: Mount Keen Walking Route

images.title: Callum Black / Trig point, Mount Keen
images.caption: Trig point, Mount Keen. The fairly uniformly rounded Mount Keen ends in a little rocky outcrop holding the summit trig point.

images.title: Callum Black / Mount Keen path
images.caption: Mount Keen path. Path leading to the summit of Scotland's most easterly Munro. Without a properly constructed path the walker's route to a polular hill like this would quickly turn into a wide strip of eroded moorland.

images.title: Neil MacLeod / Looking down Glen Mark
images.caption: Looking down Glen Mark from Couternach. The Glen Mark track and Mounth path were like an ice rink, the planned ascent of Mount Keen was abandoned. Couternach's slopes made for slow progress through deep snow.

images.title: Iain McDonald / Water of Mark
images.caption: Water of Mark. View towards the Gilfumman cliff face, over the Cowiehillocks Plantation and the Water of Mark.

images.title: Callum Black / Queen's Well
images.caption: Queen's Well. Beneath the granite arms of the well (reflected here in the water) lies a spring of exceptionally clear water.

images.title: Graham Benny / The Mounth path from Glen Esk to Ballater
images.caption: The Mounth path from Glen Esk to Ballater. Junction where the path leaves the land rover track at 670m. Path forks further on with the more frequently used right branch leading to Mount Keen in the background.

images.title: Callum Black / Couternach
images.caption: Couternach. A small but prominent hill above Glenmark. The distinctive hill at the left of the picture is Craig of Doune.

images.title: Karl and Ali / Invermark Castle (remains of)
images.caption: Invermark Castle (remains of)

description: This is the shortest route to the summit of Mount Keen, the most easterly of the Scottish Munros. It starts at the Invermark car park in Glen Esk and heads through Glen Mark to the summit.  The path is quite good for most of the route but become rockier towards the summit. There are fabulous views of Glen Esk, Loch Lee and the Cairngorms. Look out for red deer as you make your way through the beautiful Glen Mark. Mount Keen stands at 939 m (3,081 feet). The walk will probably take about 5-7  hours.
